If youve ever run an interior or sanitary business, you already know the truth no one likes to admit:

Finding genuine clients is harder than delivering the actual project.


Some platforms send random numbers.

Some pass outdated leads.

And some dont even tell you where the lead came from.

You end up guessing the clients intent, chasing people who arent serious, or spending hours calling numbers that never pick up.


When we were building Interior bazzar, this was one of the biggest complaints we heard from hundreds of business owners.


Thats why we created something small but powerful

a tool that gives business owners complete clarity before they even make the first call.


We call it the Smart Tag System.


Why We Built the Smart Tag System

The idea started during one of our early research calls.

An interior contractor from Pune told us:


If I just knew whether a client is actually serious or just browsing, it would save half my time.


That sentence alone shaped the system.


The goal was simple:

Every business should know exactly how their lead was generated without guessing, without confusion.


The Smart Tag System is the result of that promise.


The Four Smart Tags and What They Really Mean

Instead of dumping leads into your dashboard, Interior bazzar adds a tag that tells you the story behind every client.


Not just Where did this lead come from?

But also:


How strong is the clients intent?

What stage are they in?

How ready are they to hire?


Heres what each tag really means in everyday business language:


1. Normal The Basic Inquiry Client

These are people who have a general requirement and are exploring options.


Think of someone who says:

Bathroom ka renovation karwana hai. Budget decide nahi kiya.


Theyre interested, but early in their journey.

Perfect for businesses that are comfortable nurturing clients and building trust from scratch.


2. Intent The I Know What I Want Client

This client has clarity.

They know their budget, their timeline, and their exact need.


Something like:

2BHK full interior, budget 69 lakhs, looking to start in next 20 days.


These clients usually respond faster and convert quicker because they already know what theyre looking for.


3. AI Filtered The Perfect Match Client

Here, AI does the heavy lifting.


The system checks:


Does the clients need match your services?

Are you located in the right area?

Does your average project budget fit their requirement?

Have similar clients converted before?


When all signals align, the client gets tagged as AI Filtered.


This is where technology saves you hours by removing mismatched, irrelevant inquiries.


4. Human Verified The Ready to Start Client

This is the highest-quality tag.


Before this tag is applied, the Interior bazzar team:


Calls the client

Confirms the requirement

Checks timeline

Confirms budget

Ensures they are ready to hire


These are clients who dont say, Let me think.

They say, Yes, I want to start.


For any business looking for near-guaranteed quality, these are your gold-standard leads.


Why These Tags Matter More Than You Think

Most platforms give you leads.

Interior bazzar gives you clarity.


A business owner should never wonder:


Lead genuine hai?

Is it worth calling?

Will this client even pick up?


With the Smart Tag System, you can look at a tag and instantly know:


How urgent the client is

What kind of conversation to expect

How much time to invest

How likely they are to convert

Its like walking into a meeting already knowing the persons mindset.


The Real Advantage: Prioritizing Your Energy

Your time is limited.

Your teams bandwidth is limited.

Your follow-up capacity is limited.


The Smart Tag System helps you use your time where it matters most.


Human Verified Call immediately

AI Filtered High-priority follow-up

Intent Quick response

Normal Nurture at your pace


This simple clarity can double your conversions without increasing your workload.


Built for Transparency, Not Tricks

Interior bazzar was never meant to be just another listing platform.

The Smart Tag System reflects that.


Its designed so every business big or small knows the truth behind every client.

No hidden filters.

No confusion.

Just clean, transparent, meaningful information.


Because when you understand your lead source, you dont just close more deals

you build better relationships, offer better service, and grow with confidence.

"}
fields.author: Harsh Thapa

fields.title: Why Ancient Architecture Still Outshines Modern Buildings?
fields.description:
{"delta":"{\"ops\":[{\"insert\":\"Stand in front of the Pantheon in Rome, built nearly 2,000 years ago, and you'll feel something that most modern buildings can't deliver. That structure has survived earthquakes, wars, weather, and the collapse of entire civilizations.\\n\\nNow walk through any contemporary office park built in the 1980s. Half those buildings are already falling apart.\\n\\nThere's a reason people travel across the world to see ancient temples, medieval cathedrals, and centuries-old palaces, but nobody's buying plane tickets to photograph suburban strip malls or generic glass towers. Ancient architecture wasn't just better at survivingit was better at mattering.\\n\\nThey Built Things to Last Forever\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Ancient builders had a completely different mindset than modern architects. They weren't thinking about 30-year mortgages or building codes that change every decade. They were building for eternity, and they meant it literally.\\n\\nThe Pyramids at Giza have been standing for 4,500 years. The Parthenon in Athens is 2,500 years old and still magnificent despite being partially destroyed. Compare that to modern buildings where concrete starts crumbling after fifty years and we consider a hundred-year-old structure \\\"historic.\\\"\\n\\nAncient builders achieved this through massive overengineering. They didn't calculate the minimum material needed to meet safety standardsthey used way more stone, brick, and mortar than structurally necessary. The walls are thicker than they need to be. The foundations go deeper than required. This \\\"wasteful\\\" approach meant these buildings could handle stresses their creators never imagined.\\n\\nRoman concrete is genuinely superior to what we use today in many applications. Modern concrete degrades, especially in water. Roman concrete used in harbors actually gets stronger when exposed to seawater. We only figured out why in the last decadevolcanic ash in their mixture creates a chemical reaction with saltwater that reinforces the structure over time. Two thousand years later, we're still learning from their techniques.\\n\\nAncient buildings also required almost no maintenance compared to modern structures. A stone cathedral from 1200 AD basically just sits there being a cathedral. Modern buildings need constant HVAC maintenance, elevator repairs, waterproofing, structural inspections, and a dozen other ongoing expenses. The Colosseum hasn't had its HVAC system serviced once in two millennia because it doesn't need one.\\n\\nThey Worked With Nature, Not Against It\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Ancient and traditional architecture grew directly from the environment it occupied. Builders used local materials because transporting stone or timber hundreds of miles was difficult and expensive. This created buildings that belonged to their landscape in ways modern architecture rarely achieves.\\n\\nIn Rajasthan, traditional buildings use thick stone walls and small windows because the desert climate demands it. In Kerala, traditional homes have sloped roofs and open courtyards because of heavy monsoon rains. In the Mediterranean, whitewashed walls and shaded courtyards combat intense sun. Each region developed architectural solutions perfectly adapted to local conditions over centuries of trial and refinement.\\n\\nThese weren't just aesthetic choicesthey were sophisticated climate control systems that worked without electricity. Thick stone walls absorb heat during the day and release it at night, naturally regulating temperature. Central courtyards create air circulation through convection. Window placement captures breezes while blocking harsh sun. These passive systems kept buildings comfortable in extreme climates without burning fossil fuels.\\n\\nModern architecture largely abandoned this knowledge in favor of mechanical climate control. We build identical glass boxes in Mumbai and Minnesota, then compensate for their terrible environmental performance by running air conditioning constantly. Ancient builders would consider this approach insane.\\n\\nThe integration with nature went beyond climate response. Japanese temples sit within landscapes as if they grew there naturally. Greek temples on hilltops become part of the topography rather than imposing on it. Medieval European towns follow the contours of hills and rivers. Modern development often bulldozes terrain flat and builds generic structures that could exist anywhere.\\n\\nThe Craftsmanship We've Lost\"},{\"attributes\":{\"header\":2},\"insert\":\"\\n\"},{\"insert\":\"Walk through any ancient cathedral, temple, or palace and you'll see details that would be impossible to afford today. Not impossible to createimpossible to afford. The level of skilled handwork in ancient buildings is staggering.\\n\\nStone carvers spent years creating decorative elements for buildings they'd never see completed. Stand in front of the Pantheon in Rome, built nearly 2,000 years ago, and you'll feel something that most modern buildings can't deliver. That structure has survived earthquakes, wars, weather, and the collapse of entire civilizations.


Now walk through any contemporary office park built in the 1980s. Half those buildings are already falling apart.


There's a reason people travel across the world to see ancient temples, medieval cathedrals, and centuries-old palaces, but nobody's buying plane tickets to photograph suburban strip malls or generic glass towers. Ancient architecture wasn't just better at survivingit was better at mattering.


They Built Things to Last Forever

Ancient builders had a completely different mindset than modern architects. They weren't thinking about 30-year mortgages or building codes that change every decade. They were building for eternity, and they meant it literally.


The Pyramids at Giza have been standing for 4,500 years. The Parthenon in Athens is 2,500 years old and still magnificent despite being partially destroyed. Compare that to modern buildings where concrete starts crumbling after fifty years and we consider a hundred-year-old structure \"historic.\"


Ancient builders achieved this through massive overengineering. They didn't calculate the minimum material needed to meet safety standardsthey used way more stone, brick, and mortar than structurally necessary. The walls are thicker than they need to be. The foundations go deeper than required. This \"wasteful\" approach meant these buildings could handle stresses their creators never imagined.


Roman concrete is genuinely superior to what we use today in many applications. Modern concrete degrades, especially in water. Roman concrete used in harbors actually gets stronger when exposed to seawater. We only figured out why in the last decadevolcanic ash in their mixture creates a chemical reaction with saltwater that reinforces the structure over time. Two thousand years later, we're still learning from their techniques.


Ancient buildings also required almost no maintenance compared to modern structures. A stone cathedral from 1200 AD basically just sits there being a cathedral. Modern buildings need constant HVAC maintenance, elevator repairs, waterproofing, structural inspections, and a dozen other ongoing expenses. The Colosseum hasn't had its HVAC system serviced once in two millennia because it doesn't need one.


They Worked With Nature, Not Against It

Ancient and traditional architecture grew directly from the environment it occupied. Builders used local materials because transporting stone or timber hundreds of miles was difficult and expensive. This created buildings that belonged to their landscape in ways modern architecture rarely achieves.


In Rajasthan, traditional buildings use thick stone walls and small windows because the desert climate demands it. In Kerala, traditional homes have sloped roofs and open courtyards because of heavy monsoon rains. In the Mediterranean, whitewashed walls and shaded courtyards combat intense sun. Each region developed architectural solutions perfectly adapted to local conditions over centuries of trial and refinement.


These weren't just aesthetic choicesthey were sophisticated climate control systems that worked without electricity. Thick stone walls absorb heat during the day and release it at night, naturally regulating temperature. Central courtyards create air circulation through convection. Window placement captures breezes while blocking harsh sun. These passive systems kept buildings comfortable in extreme climates without burning fossil fuels.


Modern architecture largely abandoned this knowledge in favor of mechanical climate control. We build identical glass boxes in Mumbai and Minnesota, then compensate for their terrible environmental performance by running air conditioning constantly. Ancient builders would consider this approach insane.


The integration with nature went beyond climate response. Japanese temples sit within landscapes as if they grew there naturally. Greek temples on hilltops become part of the topography rather than imposing on it. Medieval European towns follow the contours of hills and rivers. Modern development often bulldozes terrain flat and builds generic structures that could exist anywhere.


The Craftsmanship We've Lost

Walk through any ancient cathedral, temple, or palace and you'll see details that would be impossible to afford today. Not impossible to createimpossible to afford. The level of skilled handwork in ancient buildings is staggering.


Stone carvers spent years creating decorative elements for buildings they'd never see completed. Painters devoted lifetimes to frescoes in single rooms. Craftsmen developed techniques so specialized that entire guilds existed around one aspect of construction. This wasn't because ancient societies were wealthierthey simply valued permanence and beauty over speed and cost efficiency.


Look closely at carved stone capitals in Gothic cathedrals. Each one is unique, hand-carved by artisans who treated their work as a form of devotion. The mathematical precision in Islamic geometric patterns, created without computers, demonstrates mastery that few modern craftspeople possess. Japanese temple carpentry uses complex joinery without nails or screws, assembled with tolerances measured in fractions of millimeters.


This craftsmanship created buildings with genuine character. Every ancient structure has quirks, irregularities, and unique details because human hands made every element. Modern buildings, constructed from standardized components, have a sameness that can feel sterile. There's a reason people describe ancient buildings as having \"soul\"the human effort invested in their creation remains visible and tangible.


The craftsmen themselves understood buildings holistically in ways modern specialization has fragmented. A master builder in the Middle Ages understood stone, carpentry, mathematics, engineering, art, and how all these elements worked together. Today, construction involves dozens of specialized contractors who rarely understand the whole picture. This fragmentation often creates buildings where different systems work against each other rather than in harmony.


Cultural Identity Built in Stone

Ancient architecture served as a civilization's autobiography written in stone and brick. You can understand a culture's values, beliefs, technology, and worldview by studying what they built.


Egyptian pyramids demonstrate a society focused on death, the afterlife, and divine kingship. Greek temples show a culture that prized proportion, reason, and human-scaled beauty. Gothic cathedrals reveal medieval Christianity's focus on reaching toward heaven. Mughal architecture in India displays cultural synthesis and imperial ambition. Each expresses something essential about the people who created it.


Modern architecture often lacks this cultural specificity. Global stylethe glass-and-steel aesthetic that dominates business districts worldwidecould be anywhere. A commercial building in Singapore looks identical to one in So Paulo or Stockholm. This architectural homogenization reflects globalization but loses the sense of place and cultural identity that ancient architecture provided.


Traditional architecture also preserved cultural knowledge across generations. Building techniques, mathematical principles, astronomical observations, and religious symbolism were all embedded in physical structures. A traditional Hindu temple encodes vast amounts of geometric and spiritual knowledge in its design. Gothic cathedrals contain sophisticated mathematics and engineering principles. These buildings functioned as three-dimensional textbooks that preserved knowledge even when written records disappeared.


The symbolic significance of ancient architecture gave buildings meaning beyond their practical function. A cathedral wasn't just a large gathering spaceit represented heaven on earth, with every element carrying symbolic weight. A traditional Chinese home wasn't just shelterits orientation, proportions, and design reflected cosmological principles and social hierarchies. This layered meaning made buildings important in ways that purely functional modern structures often aren't.

What We Sacrificed for Speed and Profit

Modern architecture isn't worse because architects became less talented or builders less skilled. It's worse because we changed what we value. Ancient societies built for permanence, beauty, and cultural expression. Modern society builds for cost efficiency, speed, and maximum rentable square footage.


Financial pressures dominate contemporary construction. Developers need to recoup investments quickly, which means building fast with cheap materials. Owners want minimal maintenance costs, which drives standardization. Tenants expect modern amenities, which requires complex systems that need constant maintenance. These practical concerns create buildings optimized for short-term economics rather than long-term value.


Building codes and regulations, while improving safety, also standardize architecture in ways that discourage innovation and uniqueness. Zoning laws, fire codes, accessibility requirements, and structural standards all constrain design. Ancient builders faced no such restrictionsthey could experiment, take risks, and create the extraordinary.


The loss of patron relationships also changed architecture fundamentally. Ancient buildings often had single visionary patronskings, popes, wealthy merchantswho funded construction over decades without demanding immediate returns. Modern buildings serve multiple stakeholders with conflicting interests and tight budgets. This produces compromise and mediocrity.


We've also lost the luxury of time. Medieval cathedrals took centuries to complete, with multiple generations of builders contributing to a shared vision. Modern buildings must finish within a few years to satisfy financing requirements. This time pressure eliminates the possibility of the considered craftsmanship that characterized ancient construction.


Can We Learn Anything?

The success of ancient architecture suggests we've made some wrong turns. We don't need to abandon modern technology or return to hand-carving every stone, but we could reconsider what we value in buildings.


Durability deserves more emphasis. Building structures that last centuries rather than decades reduces resource consumption and environmental impact long-term. Using more material upfront costs more initially but less over time when you factor in demolition and rebuilding costs.


Climate-responsive design makes more sense than ever with energy costs and environmental concerns. Ancient passive cooling and heating techniques could reduce our dependence on mechanical systems. Adapting buildings to local climates rather than forcing identical designs everywhere would improve both comfort and sustainability.


Craftsmanship and detail don't require returning to pre-industrial methods. Modern technology could enable high-quality custom work at scale if we valued it enough to pay for it. Digital fabrication allows complex custom elements at reasonable costswe just rarely choose to use this capability.


Cultural expression through architecture matters for creating places people care about. Buildings that reflect local culture, materials, and traditions create stronger communities than generic international style structures. This doesn't mean copying historical styles, but learning from how ancient architecture achieved cultural resonance.


The fundamental lesson from ancient architecture isn't about specific techniques or stylesit's about priority. When societies prioritized permanence, beauty, and cultural meaning over speed and profit, they created buildings that outlasted empires. Our priorities produce buildings we demolish after fifty years. That's not inevitableit's a choice we keep making.

"}

Remember the last time you needed a plumber?

You probably opened Justdial, scrolled through twenty names, and started calling. Half didn't pick up. A few quoted prices that made your eyes water. One showed up three days late. Sound familiar?


Now imagine doing that for your entire home interior.

The stakes are higher. The budgets are bigger. And the wrong choice doesn't just cost you moneyit costs you months of stress and a home that doesn't feel like yours.


That's the problem with how things work right now.


What Traditional Platforms Actually Give You

Let's be honest about what happens when you search \"interior designers in Delhi NCR\" on most platforms. You get a list. Sometimes it's sorted by who paid for an ad. Sometimes it's alphabetical. Sometimes it's just random.


The platform's job ends there. They've connected you to a phone number. What happens next?

That's your problem.


So you start calling. Some numbers ring forever. Others are businesses that closed two years ago but nobody bothered updating the listing. A few are actually interior designers, but they only do commercial projects and you need someone for your 2BHK. One person sounds perfect until you mention your budget and they laughnot with you, at you.

By evening, you've made fifteen calls. You have two maybe-possibilities and a headache.

The platforms don't care. They got their listing fee or their ad revenue. Whether you found someone good? Not their concern.


What Verification Actually Changes

Here's what we do differently. Before any business appears on Interior bazzar, someone from our team has already had the conversation you were going to have.

We call them. We ask what kind of projects they take. We check if the number works. We confirm they're actually located where they claim. We find out their budget rangenot just what they say on their profile, but what they're genuinely comfortable working with.

If they tell us they specialize in luxury villas, we don't show them to someone renovating a small apartment. If they're based in Gurgaon and don't travel to Noida, we don't waste anyone's time pretending otherwise.

This sounds basic. It is basic. But nobody else does it because it takes work. Real work. The kind that doesn't happen automatically with an algorithm.


Why This Matters More Than You Think

Let's say you're a modular kitchen dealer in Mumbai. You paid for ads on three platforms. You're getting inquiries. Great, except half of them are people \"just checking prices\" with no intention to buy. A quarter are from cities you don't serve. And the rest? Maybe one or two turn into actual projects.

Your time isn't free. Every fake inquiry is time you're not spending with real customers.

Now flip it around. You're a homeowner looking for affordable interior designers near you. You don't have time to call fifty people. You need maybe three good options. But the platforms give you fifty names and tell you to figure it out yourself.

Both sides lose. The business wastes time on bad leads. The customer wastes time on bad listings.

Verification fixes both problems at once.


The Part About AI and Humans

We use AI, sure. It helps match locations and budgets fast. But AI can't tell if someone's actually serious about taking new clients. It can't gauge if a business is responsive or flaky. It can't spot when a listing smells off.

That's why actual people on our team do the final check. We're not just running names through a database. We're having conversations. We're asking follow-up questions. We're building a directory where every name has been vouched for by someone who actually talked to them.

When you search for interior designers in Bangalore on our platform, those ten results aren't just ten random names. They're ten businesses we'd feel comfortable referring to our own family.


What You Get Out of This

For businesses:

Genuine inquiries from people ready to hire. Not tire-kickers. Not bots. Actual humans with actual budgets looking for what you offer.


For customers:

A shortlist that actually makes sense. No dead numbers. No mismatched services. No surprises about who serves your area or fits your budget.

It's not revolutionary. It's just doing the obvious thing that everyone else skipped because it seemed like too much effort.


The Real Difference

Other platforms treat you like a transaction. List posted, payment received, good luck with the rest.

We treat this like what it actually ispeople trying to find other people they can trust with something important. Your home matters. Your business matters. The connection between the two should be built on something more solid than whoever paid for the top ad spot this week.

That's why verification isn't just a feature for us. It's the entire point. Without it, we're just another directory adding to the noise. With it, we're finally giving people what they've been asking for all along: listings they can actually rely on.


Try searching for verified interior leads near you. See the difference yourself.

Because once you've experienced what it's like when someone's already done the homework, going back to the old way feels pointless.


#FindYourInteriorMatch

Terms and Conditions

Effective Date: 13 October 2025

Last Updated: 13 October 2025


Welcome to Interior bazzar (we, us, or our).

These Terms and Conditions (Terms) govern your access to and use of our website https://www.interiorbazzar.com (Website) and all related digital marketing and business listing services (collectively, the Services).

By accessing or using our Website, you agree to comply with and be bound by these Terms.

If you do not agree, please discontinue use immediately.


1. About Our Platform

Interior bazzar is an Interior & Sanitary B2B and B2C Aggregator Platform that connects verified businesses and consumers through digital marketing, listing, and visibility solutions.

We provide marketing, listing, and branding tools to businesses in the interior and sanitary industry.

We do not sell products, act as a broker, or guarantee specific leads or sales.

All payments are for digital marketing, listing, or promotional subscription services only.


2. Eligibility

By using our Website, you confirm that:

You are at least 18 years old.

You have the legal authority to enter into this agreement.

You will use the Website in compliance with applicable laws and these Terms.

If you are registering on behalf of a company, you represent that you have authorization to bind that company to these Terms.


3. Use of Services

When using our Services, you agree to:

Provide accurate, current, and complete information during registration.

Maintain the confidentiality of your account credentials.

Use the Website only for lawful purposes related to business marketing or discovery.

Refrain from posting, sharing, or promoting misleading, harmful, or unlawful content.

We reserve the right to suspend or terminate accounts that violate these Terms or engage in suspicious activities.


4. Business Listings and Content

a. User Responsibility

You are responsible for the accuracy and authenticity of any content (including business information, images, logos, and descriptions) submitted for publication on our Website.

By submitting content, you grant Interior Bazzar a non-exclusive, royalty-free license to display, distribute, and promote your listing as part of our Services.

b. Review and Removal

We reserve the right to review, modify, or remove content that:

Violates applicable laws or third-party rights.

Contains false, defamatory, or deceptive claims.

Includes prohibited or offensive material.


5. Subscription and Payments

Our services are offered on a subscription basis, billed as per the selected plan.

All payments are processed securely through authorized payment gateways (e.g., Razorpay, PhonePe).

Subscription fees are non-refundable once services commence, except as outlined in our Refund Policy.

Pricing, plans, and features may change periodically, but you will be notified before any renewal or modification.


6. Intellectual Property Rights

All intellectual property, including content, design, graphics, trademarks, and technology on the Website, is owned by or licensed to Interior bazzar.

Users may not reproduce, distribute, modify, or exploit any part of the Website without prior written consent.

Any unauthorized use may result in legal action.


7. Limitation of Liability

To the maximum extent permitted by law:

Interior bazzar is not liable for any indirect, incidental, or consequential damages arising from use of the Website or Services.

We do not guarantee the accuracy or completeness of listings, nor do we endorse any third-party business featured on the platform.

Users and businesses are solely responsible for verifying authenticity before making any transactions or collaborations.


8. Indemnification

You agree to indemnify and hold harmless Interior bazzar, its officers, employees, and partners from any claims, damages, liabilities, or losses resulting from:

Violation of these Terms;

Misuse of the Website or Services; or

Infringement of third-party rights.


9. Third-Party Services

Our Website may include links to external websites, advertisers, or payment gateways.

We are not responsible for the content, privacy practices, or actions of these third-party sites.

Use of such sites is at your own risk.

10. Termination

We may suspend or terminate your account without prior notice if:

You breach these Terms;

Engage in unlawful or fraudulent activities; or

Misuse our platform in any manner.

Termination does not affect any prior obligations or outstanding payments.


11. Governing Law and Jurisdiction

These Terms are governed by and construed under the laws of India.

Any disputes arising under or in connection with these Terms shall be subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the courts of New Delhi, India.


12. Updates to Terms

We may update or modify these Terms from time to time to reflect changes in services, policies, or laws.

Any changes will be posted on this page with the revised Effective Date.

Continued use of our Services after updates implies acceptance.


13. Contact Information

For any questions regarding these Terms and Conditions, please contact:

Mail: marketing@interiorbazzar.com | help@interiorbazzar.com

Website: https://www.interiorbazzar.com

"}

Return and Refund Policy

Effective Date: October 2025

Last Updated: October 2025


Thank you for choosing Interior bazzar.

This Return and Refund Policy (Policy) explains the terms under which payments made for digital marketing, listing, and promotional services are handled.

By subscribing to or purchasing any service on https://www.interiorbazzar.com (Website), you agree to this Policy.


1. Nature of Our Services

Interior bazzar is a digital Interior & Sanitary B2B and B2C Aggregator Platform that provides:

Business listings

Marketing and promotional visibility

AI-based visibility and analytics services

Category placements, dashboard access, and online support

All services are intangible digital services, not physical goods or deliverable items.

Hence, traditional product return policies do not apply.


2. Subscription and Payment

All payments for marketing or subscription plans (including but not limited to Special Offer, Verified Seller, Leader Network, Scale with Partner, Grow with AI, and Luxury Plans) are processed through secure third-party payment gateways (e.g., Razorpay, PhonePe).

By purchasing a plan, you acknowledge that:

You have read and understood the plans features and scope before making payment.

You authorize us to process payment through your chosen method.

Once activated, the service is considered delivered and utilized.


3. Refund Eligibility

Duplicate payment or transaction error

100% refund after verification

Payment deducted but service not activated within 10 business days

100% refund

Technical or gateway failure during transaction

100% refund upon gateway confirmation

Service purchased but canceled before activation

Refund after deduction of 10% (processing charges)

Services already activated and used (listing published, campaign started, visibility assigned)

Not eligible


4. Non-Refundable Situations

Refunds will not be provided in the following cases:

Services have already commenced, accessed, or used by the client.

Business listing, content creation, or advertisement setup has been completed.

Delays or outcomes resulting from the clients lack of participation, incorrect information, or third-party issues.

Plan cancellations after campaign activation or renewal.

Any dissatisfaction arising from expectations beyond the defined plan features.

interiobazzar@gmail.com

Users may request cancellation before service activation or publication of listings.

Once services are activated or visibility is assigned, cancellation is not possible.

Renewal cancellations must be requested at least 7 days before the renewal date to avoid automatic renewal.

All cancellations must be made through a written request to help@interiorbazzar.com.


6. Dispute Resolution

If you believe your refund or service handling was incorrect, please contact us at help@interiorbazzar.com within 7 days of the transaction.

Our support team will investigate and provide a resolution based on this policy.


7. Policy on Promotional and Trial Offers

Promotional, discounted, or trial-based subscriptions are non-refundable.

Once availed, these offers are considered used.

Refunds are not applicable for partial months or unused service days.


8. Modification of Policy

Interior bazzar reserves the right to modify, update, or revise this Policy at any time to reflect operational or legal requirements.

All changes will be published on this page with the updated Effective Date.

Continued use of our platform after updates implies acceptance.


9. Contact Information

For all payment, refund, or cancellation inquiries, please contact:

Mail: marketing@interiorbazzar.com | help@interiorbazzar.com

Website: https://www.interiorbazzar.com

"}

Disclaimer

Interior bazzar is a networking and marketing services platform for interior and sanitary industry professionals.

We connect verified businesses and consumers through marketing, advertising, and visibility services.

We do not sell physical products, act as an aggrigator, or guarantee specific results or outcomes.

All information provided on our platform is for marketing and informational purposes only.

Users are advised to verify details independently before making any business or purchasing decisions.

By using our website https://www.interiorbazzar.com, you acknowledge that Interior bazzar is not liable for any business transactions, financial losses, or service outcomes between users or listed parties.

Privacy Policy

Effective Date:  01 August 2025

Last Updated:  01 August 2025


Welcome to Interior bazzar (we, us, our, or the Platform).

We respect your privacy and are committed to protecting your information.

This Privacy Policy explains how we collect, use, and safeguard your data when you visit https://www.interiorbazzar.com or use our digital marketing and listing services.

By using our Platform, you agree to this Privacy Policy.


1. Who We Are

Interior bazzar is Interior & Sanitary B2B and B2C Aggregator Platform that connects verified interior and sanitary businesses with consumers through digital marketing, listing, and promotional services.

We do not sell physical products or guarantee leads; all services are digital and marketing-oriented.


2. Information We Collect

We collect information to deliver and improve our services responsibly.

A. Business Information

Business name, logo, address, and contact details

Business category, description, and service area

GST number (optional)

B. Personal Information

Name, email address, phone number (for communication or account creation

C. Transaction Information

Payment data processed securely by authorized payment gateways (e.g., Razorpay, PhonePe).

We never store full card or UPI information on our servers.

D. Technical Information

Device type, IP address, browser details, usage statistics

Cookies and analytics data (Google Analytics, Meta Pixel, etc.)


3. How We Use Your Information

We use your data only for legitimate purposes, including to:

Create and verify business listings.

Provide marketing and advertising services.

Communicate service updates and offers.

Process subscriptions and payments.

Analyze usage and improve user experience.

Prevent fraud and ensure security.

Comply with legal requirements.


4. Data Sharing and Disclosure

We do not sell or rent personal information.

Data may be shared only with:

Payment Gateways & Banks (for secure transactions)

Authorized Service Providers (analytics, email, hosting)

Legal Authorities (when required by law)

All partners follow confidentiality and data-protection standards.


5. Data Retention

We retain information as long as needed to provide services and meet legal obligations.

Data is securely deleted or anonymized when no longer required.


6. Data Security

Your information is protected through:

SSL encryption (HTTPS)

Access controls and audits

Secure servers and backups

PCI-DSS compliant payment partners


7. Your Rights

You may:

Access or update your information.

Request correction or deletion (subject to law).

Opt out of marketing emails.

To exercise rights, email help@interiorbazzar.com.


8. Cookies and Tracking

We use cookies to enhance your experience and analyze traffic.

You can disable cookies in browser settings; some features may not work properly.


9. Third-Party Links

Our site may link to external platforms (payment gateways, social media, etc.).

We are not responsible for their privacy policies please review them independently.


10. Legal Compliance

Interior bazzar complies with:

IT Act 2000 (Sections 43A & 72A)

SPDI Rules 2011

Global privacy principles (GDPR alignment)

Policies of Razorpay, PhonePe, Google Ads, and AdSense


11. Policy Updates

We may revise this Privacy Policy to reflect changes in law or business process.

Latest version will always be available at https://www.interiorbazzar.com/privacy-policy.

Continued use implies acceptance of the updated terms.


12. Contact Us

Mail: marketing@interiorbazzar.com | help@interiorbazzar.com

Website: https://www.interiorbazzar.com

"}

Cookie Policy

Effective Date: 13 October 2025

Last Updated: 13 October 2025


This Cookie Policy explains how Interior bazzar (we, us, or our) uses cookies and similar technologies on our website https://www.interiorbazzar.com (Website).

It describes what cookies are, how we use them, and how you can manage your preferences.

By continuing to browse or use our Website, you consent to the use of cookies as outlined in this policy.


1. What Are Cookies

Cookies are small text files placed on your computer or mobile device when you visit a website.

They help websites recognize your device, remember user preferences, and improve overall functionality and performance.

Cookies do not grant access to your device or any personal information beyond what you choose to share.


2. How We Use Cookies

We use cookies to enhance your browsing experience and optimize our services. The main purposes include:

a. Essential Functionality:

To enable basic website operations such as secure login, navigation, and access to service areas.

b. Performance and Analytics:

To understand how users interact with our Website and improve usability through analytics tools like Google Analytics.

c. Advertising and Marketing:

To display relevant advertisements and measure campaign effectiveness using tools such as Google Ads and Meta Pixel.

d. User Preferences:

To remember your region, language, and previous settings for a personalized experience.

e. Security:

To help identify and prevent fraudulent activity or unauthorized access.


3. Types of Cookies We Use

Cookies Types

Essential Cookies

\tPurpose: Support key website functionality and security

\tExample Tools: Session cookies, login authentication

Analytics Cookies

\tPurpose: Analyze user activity and improve performance

\tExample Tools: Google Analytics, Hotjar

\tAdvertising Cookies

\tPurpose: Track conversions and optimize ad campaigns

\tExample Tools: Meta Pixel, Google Ads

Functional Cookies

\tPurpose: Store user preferences and interface settings

\tExample Tools: Language or region preferences


4. Third-Party Cookies

Some cookies may be placed by third-party service providers that assist with analytics, advertising, or embedded content.

These third-party cookies are governed by their respective privacy and cookie policies, which we encourage you to review.

We do not control or manage third-party cookies once they are set on your device.


5. Managing and Disabling Cookies

You can control or disable cookies through your browser settings.

Most browsers automatically accept cookies, but you can modify your preferences to block or delete them at any time.

Please note that disabling cookies may limit access to certain features or reduce the Websites functionality.

For more information on how to manage cookies, visit:

www.aboutcookies.org

www.allaboutcookies.org

PAYMENT INFO

We use manual verification to protect data and privacy. Adding the account via net banking may take 13 hours. Once activated, follow the net-banking steps below to pay. For India, UPI is available for faster activation.


National- (India)

Account Type: Current

Account Number: 70651211205

IFSC Code: IDFB0020106

Branch: Dwarka Branch

UPI ID: feelsafe@idfcbank

Receiver Name: FEELSAFE TECHNOLOGY INDIA PRIVATE LIMITED

Supported methods: NEFT, RTGS, UPI


How to pay (India)

Initiate NEFT/RTGS from any bank or pay via UPI to the UPI ID above.

Enter the exact amount from the Order Summary.

Note the Transaction ID or take a screenshot after success.

Submit the Payment Confirmation Form to activate the subscription. (click here)


International

Account Type: Current

Account Number: 70651211205

SWIFT Code: IDFB IN BB MUM

Branch: Dwarka Branch

Receiver Name: FEELSAFE TECHNOLOGY INDIA PRIVATE LIMITED


How to pay (International)

Make an international wire using the above details and include the SWIFT code.

Pay the exact invoice amount; include any bank charges as required.

Save your bank reference/Transaction ID or receipt screenshot.

Submit the Payment Confirmation Form to finalize activation. (click here)


Helpful Notes

Processing times: UPI instant; NEFT/RTGS within banking hours; international wires 13 business days.

If paid from a different name/account, mention it in Notes to avoid delays.

GST invoice/receipt will be emailed after verification.


Trust Signals

Secure checkout badge, SSL/TLS lock icon

Logos: UPI, Visa, Mastercard, RuPay, bank transfer icons

Short reassurance: Your payment is encrypted and safe.\"


Need Help?

Subscriptions: help@interiorbazzar.com

"}

fields.question: What is InteriorBazzar?
fields.answer: InteriorBazzar is an aggregator platform that attracts potential customers via digital campaigns and shares qualified project leads with registered interior businesses and brands. We do not execute interior projects ourselves.

fields.question: Where do you operate?
fields.answer: Services currently cover India with selected international reach. Availability may expand or change over time.

fields.question: How do plans work?
fields.answer: Plans include a defined lead allocation and a lead replacement percentage. Pricing and inclusions are shown at checkout and in the dashboard.

fields.question: What payment methods are supported?
fields.answer: For India, NEFT/RTGS/UPI to the provided account/UPI; international users can pay via bank transfer (SWIFT). Follow the instructions on the payment page and submit the payment confirmation form.
